questions.text: Which of the following is not involved in renal autoregulation?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Renal sympathetic system fibers Renal sympathetic system fibers are not involved in the autoregulation of renal blood flow.

Highyeild:

Renal autoregulation refers to the ability of the kidneys to maintain a relatively constant glomerular filtration rate (GFR) and renal blood flow (RBF) despite changes in systemic blood pressure. This mechanism helps ensure that the kidneys receive a consistent blood supply for proper filtration and waste elimination.

Random:

Explanation for other options: - Renal autoregulation Tubuloglomerular feedback Increase in renal artery pressure Increase in renal blood flow Increase in GFR Increase in delivery of solute and water to macular densa , macula densa secrets a vasoactive substance constriction of afferent arteriole decrease in renal blood flow GFR back to normal. Myogenic reflex Increase in renal artery pressure stretches the walls of the afferent arterioles , afferent arterioles contracts ,increase in afferent arteriolar resistance, compensates for the increase in blood pressure ,Renal blood flow will be constant. Renin angiotensin system Angiotensin II is a potent vasoconstrictor. Efferent arterioles are more sensitive than afferent arterioles. Low levels of angiotensin II produce an increase in GFR by constricting efferent arterioles. High levels of angiotensin II decreases GFR by constricting both afferent and efferent arterioles thereby decreasing the renal blood flow

questions.text: Plasma clearance of urea = UV/P. What does Stands for?

options.label: A
options.text: Urea concentration in urine in mg/100ml

options.label: B
options.text: Urea concentration in urine in gm/24 hr

options.label: D
options.text: Urea concentration in plasma in mg/100ml

questions.correct_answer: A. Urea concentration in urine in mg/100ml
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Urea concentration in urine in mg/100ml Clearance of a substance is the volume of plasma free of that substance in a given time. Cl = UV/P Cl – clearance U – Urine concentration of the substance V – Rate of urine flow P – Plasma concentration of the substance So, the ‘U' in the formula represents urea concentration in urine in mg/100mg.

Highyeild:

The plasma clearance of urea is a measure of how effectively the kidneys can remove urea (a waste product of protein metabolism) from the bloodstream and excrete it in the urine. It is calculated by dividing the product of the urine flow rate and urine urea concentration by the plasma urea concentration. The resulting value represents the volume of plasma that is completely cleared of urea per unit of time (usually expressed in ml/min). It is used to assess kidney function and the glomerular filtration rate (GFR) since the kidneys are primarily responsible for clearing urea from the blood.

Extraedge:

Renal clearance of a substance is the volume of plasma that is completely cleared of the substance by the kidneys per unit of time.

questions.text: Tetanus toxin acts on which of the following?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Synaptobrevin Tetanus toxin interferes with release of inhibitory neurotransmitters glycine and GABA. Tetanus toxin acts on docking protein ‘synaptobrevin'

Highyeild:

Synaptobrevin (also known as VAMP - vesicle-associated membrane protein) is a protein involved in synaptic vesicle exocytosis, a process essential for neurotransmitter release at nerve synapses. During this process, synaptic vesicles containing neurotransmitters fuse with the presynaptic membrane and release their contents into the synaptic cleft.

Random:

Explanation for other options: - The other proteins listed are also involved in synaptic vesicle exocytosis and neurotransmitter release, but they are not targeted by the tetanus toxin . For example: Option: A & C. Syntaxin and SNAP-25 are proteins involved in the formation of the SNARE complex, which is essential for vesicle fusion with the presynaptic membrane. Option D. NSF (N-ethylmaleimide-sensitive fusion protein) is involved in the disassembly of the SNARE complex after vesicle fusion.

questions.text: A boy presented with the intractable diarrhoea after a beach trip, stool was like rice water. The organism acts by disrupting which of the following in the interstitial epithelial cells?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Zona occludens The clinical presentation described, with intractable diarrhea and stool resembling rice water, is characteristic of cholera. Cholera is caused by infection with the bacterium Vibrio cholerae.

Highyeild:

The history and the presence of rice watery stools suggests diagnosis of Cholera. Vibrio cholera secrets Cholera toxin, Zona occludens toxin and Accessory cholera enterotoxin Zona occludens toxin disrupts tight junctions (Zona occludens) Zonula occludens are formed by 3 proteins Occludin Claudin Junctional adhesion molecule

Random:

Explanation for other options: - The other intercellular junctions listed, such as hemidesmosomes, zona adherens, and anchoring junctions, are not primarily targeted by the cholera toxin in the pathogenesis of cholera. The main mechanism of action of the toxin is the disruption of zona occludens, leading to the characteristic diarrhea and fluid loss seen in cholera.

Extraedge:

By disrupting the tight junctions (zona occludens), the cholera toxin increases the permeability of the intestinal epithelium, leading to massive water and electrolyte loss into the intestinal lumen. The resulting "rice water" stool is essentially clear and watery due to the loss of fluids and electrolytes, which can rapidly lead to severe dehydration and electrolyte imbalances.

questions.text: β hCG is structurally similar to which of the following?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

LH β hCG (human chorionic gonadotropin) is structurally similar to LH (luteinizing hormone).

Highyeild:

Human Chorionic gonadotropin (hCG) is a glycoprotein produces by synctiotrophoblasts. It is made up of α and β subunits. α Subunit of hCG is similar to the α subunits of LH, FSH and TSH. But the β Subunit of hCG has structural similarity to LH only. So, LH is the better answer. Luteinizing hormone (LH) is a hormone produced by the anterior pituitary gland. It is essential for the regulation of the female menstrual cycle and the process of ovulation. LH stimulates the release of an egg from the ovary during the menstrual cycle.

Random:

Explanation for other options: - The other hormones listed (FSH, ACTH, Oxytocin) have different functions and are not structurally similar to hCG. Adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH) regulates the production of cortisol in the adrenal glands, and oxytocin is a hormone involved in labor and lactation.

Extraedge:

hCG is primarily luteinizing and luteotrophic. It appears to act on the same receptor as that of LH. The function of hG is to prevent regression of the corpus luteum. It can be detected in blood as early as 6 days after conception and forms the basis of various tests used to identify pregnancy.

questions.text: Which of the following best describes the relationship of end diastolic volume to force of contraction of the heart?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Length tension relationship The relationship of end-diastolic volume to force of contraction of the heart is best described by the "Length-tension relationship." The Frank-Starling law of the heart is closely related to the length-tension relationship. It states that within physiological limits, the greater the volume of blood (end-diastolic volume) filling the ventricles during diastole, the more they are stretched. This stretching leads to an optimal overlap of actin and myosin filaments within the cardiac muscle fibers, resulting in a stronger force of contraction during systole (ventricular contraction).

Highyeild:

Length tension relationship – More the initial length of the muscle fiber, more is the tension generated up to a physiological limit, further increase in the initial length decreases the tension generated. Frank starling law of heart – The volume of blood ejected by the ventricle depends on the volume present in the ventricle at the end of the diastole.

Random:

Explanation for other options: - The incorrect options (2, 3, and 4) are not directly related to the relationship between end-diastolic volume and force of contraction in the heart. The correct option is the "Length-tension relationship" (or "Length-force relationship"), which describes how the initial stretching of cardiac muscle fibers (due to increased end-diastolic volume) influences the force of contraction during systole, as described by the Frank-Starling law of the heart.

questions.text: Which of the following substance follows the given transport graph?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Glucose The graph represents the carrier mediated transport (facilitated diffusion) shown by glucose. The graph shows that, the rate of diffusion of a substance increase with the increase in concentration gradient across the membrane till the carrier proteins are saturated, further increase in the concentration gradient will not increase the rate of diffusion.

Extraedge:

Passive diffusion of solute into a cell is linearly related to the concentration of solute outside the cell. Carrier proteins increase the rate of diffusion by allowing more solute to enter the cell. Facilitated diffusion, however, approaches a maximum rate as the carrier proteins become saturated with solute.

questions.text: Decrease in central venous pressure will not cause which of the following?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Increase in ANP A decrease in central venous pressure (CVP) will not cause an increase in atrial natriuretic peptide (ANP).

Highyeild:

If central venous pressure (CVP) decreases, the excitation of atrial stretch receptor is reduced and it results in increase in ADH, decrease in ANP. Hypovolemia also increase in thirst and angiotensin II.

Random:

Explanation for other options: - Option A. Increase in ADH (Antidiuretic Hormone): When CVP decreases, the body senses this as a sign of low blood volume and initiates the release of ADH to reduce urine output and conserve water. This helps to retain fluid and increase blood volume. Option C. Increase in angiotensin II: Angiotensin II is a hormone that plays a crucial role in the regulation of blood pressure. When CVP decreases, the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system (RAAS) is activated, leading to the production of angiotensin II. Angiotensin II causes vasoconstriction, retention of sodium and water, and an increase in blood pressure. Option D. Increase in thirst: A decrease in CVP and subsequent decrease in blood volume can stimulate the thirst mechanism to encourage increased fluid intake. This helps to replenish the lost fluid and raise blood volume.

Extraedge:

When CVP decreases, it is typically an indicator of reduced blood volume or venous return to the heart. In response to low CVP, the body activates compensatory mechanisms to maintain blood pressure and fluid balance.

questions.text: Which of the following ions in the thick ascending limb of the loop of henle is responsible for the resorption of divalent ions?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

K+ Potassium (K+) is responsible for the resorption of divalent ions like calcium, magnesium in the thick ascending limb of the loop of henle.

Highyeild:

Mechanism of resorption in TAL of LOH The luminal membrane contains a Na+ K+ 2Cl- co transporter Na+, K+ and Cl- ions are transported into the cell on the cotransporter Na+ is extruded from the cell by Na+ K+ ATPase in the basolateral membrane K+ and Cl- diffuse through the channels in the basolateral membrane Some portion of K+ diffuse back into the lumen This K+ leak in the lumen generates a positive electrochemical potential difference in the lumen This lumen positive potential difference drives the resorption of ions such as Na+, Mg2+, Ca2+ etc.

questions.text: Which of the following is involved in discriminative touch?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Meissner’s corpuscles. Meissner’s corpuscles are the rapidly adopting receptors present in the dermis of the non-hairy skin. Meissner’s corpuscles are encapsulated receptors. These encode : Point discrimination Precise location Tapping Flutter

Highyeild:

Meissner corpuscles consist of a cutaneous nerve ending responsible for transmitting the sensations of fine, discriminative touch and vibration.

Table:

#MANTRA

questions.text: The relaxation of the intestinal segment distal to the segment with the bolus of food during peristalsis occurs by:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

VIP The relaxation of the intestinal segment distal to the segment with the bolus of food during peristalsis is primarily mediated by VIP (Vasoactive Intestinal Peptide).

Highyeild:

The relaxation of intestinal segment distal to the segment with the bolus of food during peristalsis is due to Vasoactive intestinal Peptide (VIP) Smooth muscle contraction behind the bolus of food Substance P Acetyl choline Smooth muscle relaxation distal to the bolus of food NO (Nitric oxide) VIP (vasoactive intestinal polypeptide)

Random:

Explanation for other options: - Option: A. Substance P: Substance P is a neuropeptide that acts as a neurotransmitter in the nervous system, including the enteric nervous system. It is involved in pain perception and inflammation. However, it is not directly responsible for the relaxation of the intestinal segment during peristalsis. Instead, Substance P is known for its role in transmitting pain signals and modulating gastrointestinal motility. Option: B. Acetylcholine: Acetylcholine is a neurotransmitter that plays a vital role in the autonomic nervous system and neuromuscular junctions, including the enteric nervous system. It is a key mediator of smooth muscle contraction in the gastrointestinal tract, rather than relaxation. When released by excitatory neurons, acetylcholine binds to receptors on smooth muscle cells, leading to muscle contractions and peristaltic movements, not relaxation. Option: D. Dopamine from adrenergic fibers: Dopamine is a neurotransmitter primarily associated with the central nervous system, but it is also found in the enteric nervous system. However, dopamine released from adrenergic fibers (which are part of the sympathetic nervous system) generally has inhibitory effects on smooth muscle activity in the gastrointestinal tract. It is not involved in the relaxation of the intestinal segment during peristalsis. Instead, the sympathetic nervous system typically decreases motility and promotes "rest and digest" functions.

Extraedge:

The food bolus in the small intestine is sensed by enterochromaffin cells of the intestinal mucosa, which release 5-hydroxytryptamine (5-HT)(serotonin). The 5-HT then binds to the receptors on intrinsic primary afferent neurons (IPANs), which when activated, initiate the peristaltic reflex in that segment of the small intestine. Behind the bolus, excitatory transmitters like acetylcholine, Substance P, neuropeptide Y are released in the circular muscle, while these pathways are inhibited in the longitudinal muscle; thus this segment of small intestine (behind the bolus) contracts and lengthens.

questions.text: Which of the following decreases the amplitude and frequency of contraction in the rabbit intestine bathed in Dale’s solution?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Adrenaline In the rabbit intestine bathed in Dale's solution, the substance that would decrease the amplitude and frequency of contractions is Adrenaline (also known as epinephrine).

Highyeild:

Dale's solution is a physiological saline solution that lacks calcium ions. When the rabbit intestine is bathed in this solution, it leads to rhythmic contractions. Adrenaline is a hormone and neurotransmitter that activates adrenergic receptors, which are part of the sympathetic nervous system. Decrease in the amplitude and frequency of contraction (relaxation of the smooth muscles) is caused by sympathetic agents, that is adrenaline. Acetyl choline, Calcium chloride (CaCl2) and Barium chloride increase the amplitude and frequency of contraction

Random:

Explanation for other options: - Option: B. Acetyl choline (ACh) typically has the opposite effect, increasing the amplitude and frequency of contractions in the intestine. Option: C. CaCl2 would increase the amplitude of contractions by providing extracellular calcium, which is required for muscle contraction. Option: D. BaCl2 , on the other hand, may block muscle contraction by interfering with calcium channels, but it wouldn't decrease the amplitude and frequency of contractions in the same way as adrenaline.

questions.text: What is the duration of short term memory?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

30 – 300 seconds Short term memory lasts for 30 – 300 seconds

Highyeild:

Memory is divided into 2 forms Explicit memory / declarative memory (associated with awareness) Implicit / non declarative memory (does not involve awareness) Short term memory It lasts seconds to minutes; the encoding process for short-term explicit memory involves the hippocampus. It lasts only till the person continues to think about the number or facts. Working memory is a form of short-term memory that keeps information available, usually for very short periods of time, until the individual plans action based on it. Long term memory It stores memories that can be recollected after years or even for a lifetime. These memories are stored in various parts of the neocortex. The various parts of the memories such as, visual, auditory, olfactory, etc., are localised to the cortical regions concerned with these functions. All These parts of the memories are brought together by long-term changes in the strength of transmission at relevant synaptic junctions so that all the components are brought to consciousness when that particular memory is recalled.
